Award.AbstractNarration:
Many important systems in science and engineering, including wireless communications, complex networks such as the Internet, and neural science, have natural formulations in terms of graphs. To analyze such systems, it is important to understand the structure of the associated classes of graphs and to decompose those graphs into structured pieces. Such structural information and decomposition can then be used to provide good solutions to problems formulated in these models. This research project investigates problems concerning structure and decomposition of certain fundamental classes of graphs. Research materials arising from the project will be used to train undergraduate, graduate, and early-career researchers in this field of research.

Using structural and extremal techniques, the investigator and collaborators have recently resolved a longstanding conjecture on graphs containing no topological K5 and several conjectures on partitions of graphs and hypergraphs. This project extends this research to study related problems, including conjectures concerning non-separating paths and several problems concerning judicious partitions of graphs and hypergraphs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many real world situations can be modeled as graphs, e.g. the Internet and biological networks. Therefore, fundamental research in graph theory could provide tools and results that may be useful for solving real life problems. Frequently, solutions to problems in graph theory  require structural information of those graphs involved. 


The PI investigated the structure of graphs with forbidden topological minors and/or connectivity constraints. The main objective was to study several problems in graph theory that are related to the the long standing conjecture of Kelmans and Seymour on connectivity of those graphs which do not contain the 5 vertex complete graph as a topological minor.  Those problems include a conjecture of Hajos  on a possible generalization of the Four Color Theorem and a conjecture of Lovasz on removable paths. 


The PI worked on a series of four papers in which a proof of  the Kelmans-Seymour conjecture is presented, and those four papers were accepted for publicationin December, 2019. The PI  extended the tools and techniques on this Kelmans-Seymour conjecture to make progress on the Hajos conjecture.  The PI also obtained results on  judicious  partitions of graphs and matchings in hypergraphs.  


Most of  the research results from this project are joint work with graduate students, and one of the papers also involved an undergraduate student.  Those results were presented by the PI and his students at various conferences/workshops/seminars. Below is a list of selected publications. 




1. Bisections of graphs without short cycles (with G. Fan and J. Hou), Combinatorics, Probability, and Computing,  27 (2018) 44--59.


2. Disjoint perfect matchings in 3-uniform hypergraphs (with H. Lu and L. Zhang),  J. Graph Theory,  88  (2018) 284--293.


3.  On rainbow matchings for hypergraphs (with H. Lu),  SIAM J. Discrete Math.  32 (2018) 382--393.


4.  Almost perfect matchings in k-partite k-graphs (with H. Lu and Y. Wang), SIAM J. Discrete Math. 32 (2018) 522--533.


5. Circumference of 3-connected cubic graphs (with Q. Liu and Z. Zhang), J. Combin. Theory Ser. B, 128 (2018) 134--159.


6.  On problems about judicious bipartitions of graphs (with Y. Ji, J. Ma, and J. Yan),  J. Combin. Theory Ser. B, 139  (2019) 230--250.


7. 7-Connected graphs are 4-ordered (with R. McCarty and    Y. Wang), J. Combin. Theory Ser. B,  141  (2020) 115--135.


8. Minimum co-degree condition for perfect matchings in k-partite k-graphs (with H. Lu and Y. Wang),  J. Graph Theory} (2019), https://doi.org/10.1002/jgt.22448.


9. The Kelmans-Seymour conjecture I, special separations (with D. He and Y. Wang),  J. Combin. Theory Ser. B, (2019) https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jctb.2019.11.008


10. The Kelmans-Seymour conjecture II, 2-vertices in K4-  (with D. He and Y. Wang), J. Combin. Theory   Ser. B, (2019) https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jctb.2019.11.007


11. The Kelmans-Seymour conjecture III, 3-vertices in K4-  (with D. He and Y. Wang),  J. Combin. Theory Ser. B,  (2019) https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jctb.2019.11.006


12. The Kelmans-Seymour conjecture IV, A proof  (with D. He and Y. Wang),  J. Combin. Theory Ser. B, (2019) https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jctb.2019.12.002
